titleStmt.title: Focusing Mutations into the P. fluorescens Esterase Binding Site Increases Enantioselectivity More Effectively than Distant Mutations

div.head: reocenter [22]. Why does directed evolution usually discover distant and not close mutations? Introduction
div.p: Fully random mutagenesis would create all possible combinations of the 19 natural amino acids at each po-Changing an enzyme's catalytic properties, such as ensition in a protein. However, this is an impossibly large antioselectivity, is an important practical goal. Enzymes number of possibilities-for a 300 amino acid protein, with high enantioselectivity toward unnatural substrates it is larger than the number of atoms in the universehelp chemists make key pharmaceutical intermediates. so experimental design limits the randomness in all In addition, these changes can also reveal mechanistic random mutagenesis experiments. We refer to all mutainformation on the molecular basis for catalytic power genesis experiments that contain some randomness as and stereoselectivity of enzymes. random mutagenesis. On the other hand, saturation mutagenesis acts in a limited region because it replaces amino acids in se-

acid residues form concentric shells around the active For these two examples, more than half of the amino acid residues lie 13-22 Å from the active site, and <10% site. As one moves outward, each shell contains more amino acids. The volume of each thin shell is the differ-lie within 10 Å of the active site. Similarly, crossovers at regions of high sequence similarity are more likely to occur when DNA shuffling is used [27]. This bias of DNA shuffling is N aa in thin shell = 4p(r shell 2 d + r shell d 2 + d 3 3 ) 141.3 Å 3 / aa

div.head: Mutagenesis and Identification of Catalytically Active Mutants
div.p: We introduced all 19 possible amino acids at the selected sites one at a time by saturation mutagenesis. This procedure involved copying DNA encoding for PFE by using polymerase chain extension of both plasmid Four residues, Trp28, Val121, Phe198, and Val225 (stick representa-strands with primers containing the degenerate codons tion), lie close to the chiral acyl moiety of Ser94-MBMP (spaceat the selected site. The NNK codons gave 32 possible filling representation). The bromine (burgundy) of MBMP orients codons and coded for each of the 20 amino acids at towardVal121. His251 is the catalytic histidine. least once. N represents any of the four nucleotides (A, T, G, or C); K represents either G or T. Transformation of this mixture of plasmids into E. coli gave a mixture within the substrate binding site of Pseudomonas fluoof mutants (each transformation yielded >500 colonies). rescens esterase increase enantioselectivity for hydro-To ensure that we tested all 19 possible amino acid lysis of methyl 3-bromo-2-methylpropionate (MBMP) substitutions for Trp28 and Val121, we tested 192 colomore effectively than the method used in our previous nies, which ensures that we tested >99.8% of the 32 work, which used single random mutations in the entire possible codons (assuming equal incorporation) [37]. protein [15]. The fraction of mutants with increased en-For the Phe198 library, we tested only 96 colonies, but antioselectivity is much higher (13% versus <1%), and this still ensures that we tested 95% of the possible the changes are much larger (up to 5-fold versus 1.5codons. For the Val225 library, we screened many more fold). Researchers have previously changed substrate colonies (480), since we did not find more enantioselecspecificity by using random mutations within the subtive mutants at this position (see below) and wanted to strate binding site [28-31]. Our target substrate, MBMP, be sure that we did not miss one. was chosen for three reasons. div.head: Random mutagenesis of an entire enzyme creates
Experimental Procedures
div.p: Purification of PFE To determine enantioselectivity by the endpoint method, pure PFE General enzyme was desirable so as to avoid competing hydrolysis from Chemicals, buffers, and lysozyme were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (Oakville, ON). LB media was obtained from Difco Laborato-any other enzymes that may be present in the crude preparation.

figure.head: Figure 1 . 2 d + r shell d 2 + d 3 3 ) ( 1 )4p(r shell 2 d + r shell d 2
figure.figDesc: Figure 1. Single Mutations Closer to the Active Site Increase Enantioselectivity More Strongly than Single Distant Mutations, but Closer Amino Acids Are Rarer than Distant Ones (A) Location of single mutations that increase enzyme enantioselectivity as identified by rational design (solid symbols) or directed evolution (outline symbols). The distance is from the Cα of the mutated amino acid to the stereocenter of the substrate bound to the enzyme or to a key active site residue. The closest contact may be shorter, depending on side chain orientations. The observed enantioselectivity changes are given as activation energy differences (⌬⌬⌬G ‡ ) to simplify comparison. Although the molecular details differ for each case, closer mutations increase enantioselectivity more strongly than distant mutations. The literature data for this figure are included as Supplemental Data (available with this article online). (B) The number of amino acids in each 1 Å thick shell increases with the radius of the shell. The line shows the predicted values for a spherical enzyme with an active site in the center; see Equation 2 in the text. The points correspond to the observed numbers in the X-ray crystal structures of lipase from Pseudomonas aeruginosa (PAL, circles) and esterase from Pseudomonas fluorescens (PFE, triangles). The distances are between Cα of the amino acid residues and the stereocenter of a modeled bound substrate (a 2-methyl carboxylic acid ester). The observed numbers fit the predicted line well up to w16 Å, but are lower than predicted beyond w16 Å because one reaches the edge of the protein. The number of amino acids is for each thin shell and is not cumulative. For this reason, it decreases as the shells extend beyond the protein. More than half of the amino acid residues in these enzymes are 13-22 Å from the active site, and <10% lie within 10 Å of the active site.

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 2. A Homology Model of PFE Containing the First Tetrahedral Intermediate in Hydrolysis of (R)-MBMP

figure.head: Figure 3 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 3. Activity and Enantioselectivity of PFE Mutant Colonies (A) The fraction of colonies that catalyzed hydrolysis of p-nitrophenyl acetate after random mutagenesis at each of the four sites. Dark gray bars mark active colonies (>10% of the wild-type activity [WT activity = 1.6 × 10 -3 mol/min/l]); light gray bars mark less active colonies (1%-10% of the wild-type activity); white bars mark inactive colonies (<1% of the wild-type activity). Val225, with only 15% active clones, was the least tolerant to mutations, while Phe198 was most tolerant (42% active). (B) The enantioselectivity for colonies mutated at each site-28 ("X"), 121 (diamonds), 198 (triangles), and 225 (circles)-where the Quick E values describe the preferential hydrolysis of the S-enantiomer. Mutations at sites 198 and 225 show only small changes in enantioselectivity, while mutations at sites 28 and 121 showed dramatic increases in enantioselectivity. The range of Quick E values for some highly enantioselective mutants is large (e.g., Trp28Leu values range from 81 to 123) due to errors in measuring the very slow rate of hydrolysis of the slow-reacting enantiomer. The goal of this Quick E screening was only to identify which mutants were highly enantioselective, so we did not attempt to increase the accuracy of Quick E with highly enantioselective enzymes.

This lack of reactivity is consistent with a sterically restricted electron-rich indole ring [46] of Trp28 and the electronegative bromomethyl group and thus favors rotamers acyl binding site in PFE, as suggested by previous substrate mapping [45]. in which the bromomethyl group lies nearest position 28. For the fast-reacting enantiomer, this rotamer is reactive, while, for the slow-reacting enantiomer, it is Proposed Molecular Basis for Enantioselectivity Increase unreactive. This favoring of unreactive rotamers destabilizes the transition state for the slow-reacting enanti-Of the three possible rotamers for the MBMP acyl moiety in the substrate binding site of PFE, we suggest omer. The Val121Ser mutation causes a similar destabi-Enantioselectivity Changes of PFE and Several Mutants toward MBMP (1the fast-reacting enantiomer is shown. a Neither wild-type nor any of the mutants catalyzed hydrolysis of compound 4. nr = no reaction; na = not applicable.

figure.head: Figure 4 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 4. Proposed Orientation of MBMP in the Substrate Binding Site of PFE During catalysis, the catalytic histidine (data not shown) forms a bifurcated hydrogen bond to the serine Oγ and the OMe of the substrate. This requirement crowds the sector between these two groups; thus, only rotamers with a hydrogen in this sector (pointing down) are reactive. Mutations that increase enantioselectivity favor unreactive orientations for the slow-reacting enantiomer, thereby destabilizing the transition state. The Val121Ser mutation introduces a repulsive interaction between Ser121 and the bromomethyl substituent, while the Trp28Leu mutation acts on the other side of the binding site to remove a repulsive interaction between Trp28 and the bromomethyl substituents. These changes favor the unreactive center rotamer for the slow-reacting enantiomer.
